data.title: BitmapFont in Box2D world [Enhancement]
data.body:
Box2D requires real world unit based coordinate system to work properly (1 unit = 1 meter). The logical choice is to have a small viewport such as 32 \* 24 or even smaller depending on the game logic to avoid transformations.

Because BitmapFont uses pixels and not world units it needs to be scaled to a value between 0.01 to 0.1 to be displayed in the right size in such small viewports (otherwise it looks huge). Unfortunately BitmapFont doesn't display properly when scaled with values under 0.1, glyphs start disappearing and its behaviour is messed up.

Some other people have faced this problem before:
http://gamedev.stackexchange.com/questions/73688/why-is-my-text-is-too-large-even-when-scaled-to-05f-in-libgdx
http://www.java-gaming.org/index.php?topic=30929.0

A common suggested workaround is to use a different camera but that is not a solution if the text is part of the game (not the UI, think for instance of a 2048 type of game using Box2D or any other pyshics based puzzle game with text).

The alternative "solution" is to define a larger viewport and then transform every single displayable Box2D object dimensions before rendering (typycally defining a PxelsToMeters constant) which is far from ideal.

The information is there but it gets lost in the transformations.

Could BitmapFont be enhanced to work with small viewports? Would it be possible to somehow support providing the transformation matrix to the World coordinates to avoid extreme scaling or, alternatively, improve it to display correctly when using these scaling values?

data.title: Allow building in the Mac OS X sandbox
data.body:
I develop an IDE that I distribute [in the Mac app store](https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/nightcode/id827505032?ls=1&mt=12) that includes a template for libGDX projects. It used to build and run the projects, but due to changes in `SharedLibraryLoader` it now gets the following error: `Unable to find writable path to extract file. Is the user home directory writable?`.

It looks like this is because the OS X sandbox causes `canExecute` to return false. I made a change that should have a very low impact on everyone else: It still tests for both write and execute privileges in `getExtractedFile`, but if all attempts fail, it returns a file that _at least_ has write privileges. This makes it work in the OS X sandbox.

data.title: Drag'n Drop support for the lwjgl3 backend.
data.body:
This pull request adds support for external file drag & drop. Files (from e.g. the desktop) can be dragged in a Lwjgl3Window, causing the the Lwjgl3WindowListener to call drop(String[] files).
This is an API change, since i added that drop() method to the Lwjgl3WindowListener interface.

A use case for this are programs like level editors, where you want the user to be able to easily import assets by drag and drop. 
I added a simple test as well.

data.title: FreeType returning buffer with wrong capacity
TextureAttribute has poor extensibility due to non-abstract/interface fields usage and internal mask checking.
data.body:
TextureAttribute contains the following field, which I would like to be typed GLTexture instead of Texture:
`public final TextureDescriptor<Texture> textureDescription;`
The reasoning is that classes such as TextureArray, and others which extend the GLTexture interface can then be passed into Shaders using the existing set(Uniform, TextureDescription) methods, making the overall usage of derived Texture Types much easier and standard to implement.

This change also involves modifying the Generics on the various constructors of TextureAttribute
`public <T extends Texture> TextureAttribute (...)`

Texture is a poor choice of a superclass because it contains several hard coded GL attributes which don't apply to all types of textures.

Similarly, there should be a way to add to or modify this field, such that additional texture types (Such as Stencils or SplatMaps) can be added.
`protected static long Mask = Diffuse | Specular | Bump | Normal | Ambient | Emissive | Reflection;`

The CubeMapAttribute and some related classes could be collapsed back into a normal TextureAttribute with these changes.

data.title: glTexImage3D (and other glTexImage methods) should accept null for pixel data
Intersector causes IllegalArgumentException when no overlap happens.
data.body:
Here at the line 213 of Intersector, when overlapping polygons, if no result is found, it returns the following:

`overlap.setVertices(new float[0])`

Where overlap is a Polygon.

If we look at Polygon class, setVertices method states:
`if (vertices.length < 6) throw new IllegalArgumentException("polygons must contain at least 3 points.");`

Thus resulting in IllegalArgumentException. Instead of returning empty polygon.

data.body:
Intersector:
`public static boolean intersectPolygons (Polygon p1, Polygon p2, Polygon overlap)`

method is working presumably faulty for a specific scenario when intersecting polygons have exactly intersecting vertices, as a result this vertices get duplicated.

Here is an example:
![polytestdiag](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2115888/12695409/b3a08cbe-c766-11e5-8f26-125b3b726409.png)

The resulting overlap polygon has A and B vertices duplicated, resulting in a 10 size array of floats.

data.title: Polygon sprite with repeating TextureRegion by triangulating to a uniform grid
data.body:
**Problem**
I wanted to make a class, that will render a custom shaped polygon that is filled with repeating TextureRegion. This was possible to do with PolygonSprite class if "Texture" is used. But most use case require using TextureRegion instead. As a temporary solution, previously I was using PolygonSprite and a custom shader to which I was passing u/v data in order to render this. But this was bad too because it causes additional render call for each polygon, which sucks.

**Solution**
I propose using this class instead. In short it triangulates a polygon to a "grid" so that we can easily specify all u/v coordinates and pass this directly to PolygonSpriteBatch.

![schmatic2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2115888/12684968/0462ef5c-c6db-11e5-8608-f7056757efb5.png)

In order to avoid being murdered by @xoppa , a density variable is passed to specify the "grid" density, thus eliminating any connection to actual pixel size of texture region.

I did some testing and it seems to work fine, but at this stage it is not yet ready to merge, I would be happy if you guys can:
a) decide if you need this at all in libgdx - maybe many reasons why you do not
b) see if initial idea looks well implemented, test and so on

I will do some additional fixes/additions/pushes during the weekend.
